article:
'Transition Glacier' () is a glacier extending along the east coast of
Alexander Island, 8 nautical miles (15 km) long and 2 nautical miles
(3.7 km) wide, which flows east into the George VI Ice Shelf that occupies
George VI Sound along the north side of Block Mountain and Tilt Rock. The
glacier was first photographed from the air on November 23, 1935, by Lincoln
Ellsworth and mapped from these photos by W.L.G. Joerg. Surveyed in 1949 by the
Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey, and so named by them because this glacier
marks the transition between igneous rocks to the north and sedimentary rocks
to the south.
